Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Studies of Model Molecular Plasmonic Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project is to study molecular plasmonic materials. The methodology is to introduce tethered dyes onto the surface of flat gold nanoparticles in conjunction with a matrix monolayer. The resulting dye-molecule/gold-nanoparticle hybrid will be characterized by single nanoparticle spectroscopy (light scattering and fluorescence), atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and optical microscopy. Parameters to be investigated include the dye-flat gold nanoparticle spacing, orientation of transition dipoles with respect to the metal surface, absorption and fluorescence wavelength of the attached dyes, and patterned placement of dyes with respect to the particular flat gold nanoparticle's higher-order plasmon intensity pattern (mode structure). The project aims to establish general techniques for functionalizing and patterning surfaces of gold nanoparticles, and to experimentally test applications using nanoparticle?s higher-order plasmon modes for wavelength-controlled direction of photon energy. The project will also investigate the effect of adding two different dyes to spatially separated regions of the flat gold nanoparticle to further explore plasmon mediated fluorescence resonant energy transfer.
Non-technical: The project addresses fundamental research issues in a topical area of importance to materials science. Through an increased understanding of plasmonic materials, the project is expected to contribute to the development of practical devices such as optical detectors, optical switches, and chemical sensors. The project constitutes an effective integration of research and education through training of graduate and undergraduate students in a technologically significant area. Through the inherent interactions between the directed synthetic work in the chemistry laboratory and measurements in the physics laboratory, students will gain first-hand experience functioning in an interdisciplinary and integrated research program. The research project has synergistic overlap with an undergraduate nanotechnology lab that the co-PI has developed and an organic teaching lab the PI co-supervises. The undergraduate research support can extend the experience of students though hands-on experience in either of these collaborative research laboratories. Research dissemination will be through departmental web postings, presentations to undergraduates at institutional and regional research days, and presentations at conferences as well as publication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-Assembly for Harnessing Plasmon Hot Spots

INTELECTUAL MERIT

The goal of this project was to develop techniques to control the position and spacing of metal nanoparticles and fluorescent molecules. Metal nanoparticle exhibit optical resonances which serve to concentrate the optical energy at specific points on the metal nanoparticles more than a thousand fold. Additionally the distance from the metal surface must be accurately controlled. If fluorescent molecules can be accurately positioned at those points the brightness of fluorescence could be dramatic increased. Achieving this goal requires that the molecules be accurately positioned on the metal nanoparticle. Most of the work completed related to controlling the metal-dye spacing and the environment of the dye molecule.

We have refined a method to tether the fluorescent molecules on metal surfaces with a molecular spacer. Commonly gold nanoparticles are used for these studies because they are very stable (do not oxidize). Attachment of the molecules to the gold nanoparticle typically utilized a sulfur linkage at the other end of a molecular spacer. The active form of the sulfur linkage is a thiol (RSH), however thiols readily oxidize to the disulfide (RSSR). Thiols adsorb to gold forming ordered layers where the orientation of the spacer is predicable so that the distance between the gold surface and the fluorescent part of the molecule can be predicted/engineered. Unfortunately the disulfide form does not. In this work we developed a procedure to make and to store the molecules in the form of a thiol precursor which is then converted to the thiol immediately before use. We used scanning tunneling microscopy to show improvement of the ordering of the molecular layer with molecular resolution.

Another novel method to space the fluorescent dye from the metal surface is to embed the dye under the surface of a silica nanoparticle as a buried shell. This is accomplished by a three-step process. First a silica nanoparticle “core” is grown. Then the dye is attached to the surface of the silica nanoparticle. Finally a silica shell is grown over the surface-dyed core. The result is a silica nanoparticle with dye embedded below the surface. The depth of the dye below the surface is the thickness of the final silica shell. The gold nanoparticles are then aggregated with these dyed silica nanoparticles. Initial measurements show over a 120 fold enhancement in the fluorescence intensity compared to the dyed alone.

Other work as involved encapsulation the dye on a cage molecule (cucubit[7]uril) and in ionic dendrimers. These have the effect of controlling the local environment of the fluorescent molecule and to reduce the non-radiative quenching that would otherwise result in loss of fluorescent intensity due to undesirable parasitic loss processes which occur for naked molecules very close to metal surfaces.

BROADER IMPACTS

This project was an interdisciplinary collaboration between a Synthetic Organic Chemistry group (Halterman) and a Condensed Matter Physics group (Bumm). Interdisciplinary projects are ideal train grounds for today’s undergraduate and graduate students because it prepares them for interacting with professionals in different disciplines, which is essential to be competitive in today’s market place.
